item.title: Photometric binaries, mass functions, and structural parameters of 78 Galactic open clusters
item.description: Photometric binaries, mass functions, and structural parameters of 78 Galactic open clusters

item.title: Hubble Space Telescope survey of Magellanic Cloud star clusters. Photometry and astrometry of 113 clusters and early results
item.description: Homogeneous HST photometry and astrometry of 113 clusters revels unexpcted results in the context of young star clusters in the Magellanic Clouds

item.title: NGC1818 unveils the origin of the extended main-sequence turn-off in young Magellanic Clouds clusters
item.description: The turn-on in the 40 Myr-old cluster NGC1818 exclude the presence of possible age differences among cluster stars, unveiling the origin of the extended main-sequence turn-off in young Magellanic Clouds clusters

item.title: Multiple stellar populations along the red Horizontal Branch and Red Clump of Globular Clusters
item.description: Multiple stellar populations along the red Horizontal Branch and Red Clump of Globular Clusters

item.title: Mass loss along the red giant branch in 46 Globular Clusters and their multiple populations
item.description: A chromosome map to unveil stellar populations with different magnesium abundances. The case of Omega Centauri

item.title: Gaia and Hubble unveil the kinematics of stellar populations in the Type II globular clusters Omega Centauri and M 22
item.description: Internal dynamics of anomalous/type-II globular clusters combining Gaia astrometric information with HST proper motions

item.title: A chromosome map to unveil stellar populations with different magnesium abundances. The case of Omega Centauri
item.description: A chromosome map to unveil stellar populations with different magnesium abundances. The case of Omega Centauri

item.title: Multiple populations in globular clusters and their parent galaxies
item.description: By exploiting recent work based on Gaia, half of the known Type II GCs appear clustered in a distinct region of the integral of motions space, thus suggesting a common progenitor galaxy. Except for these Type II GCs, we do not find any significant difference in the MPs between clusters associated with different progenitors.
